Sir Edmund Andros (December 6, 1637 – February 24, 1714) was an English colonial administrator in North America. He was the governor of the Dominion of New England during most of its three-year existence. Andros served as governor of the provinces of New York, East and West Jersey, Virginia, and Maryland. Before his service in North America, he served as bailiff of Guernsey. Andros' tenure in New England was authoritarian and turbulent, as his views were decidedly pro-Anglican, a negative quality in a region home to many Puritans. His actions in New England resulted in his overthrow during the 1689 Boston revolt. Records documenting Andros' professional life are preserved at the New York Historical Society and the National Archives in Surrey, England.

value.value: Acquisition: "Articles of Agreement for Dividing and Valuation of Horse Neck & Other Lands in Oyster Bay [Lloyd Neck, Long Island, NY]"
Grantor[s]: John Bowne of [Flushing] & Robert Storey of New York, Attorneys to Thomas Hart of London, [England]

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Professional / Real Estate; C. Lewis Morris with John [Bradenham], London Merchant; Date of Copy Unknown, circa 18th century, dates of original content are September 26, 27, 29 & October 16, 1678; John Ware bill of exchange; S.V. Cortlandt, Mayor; Thomas Cooper with Edward Shipping of Boston, [MA]; Samuel Wilson for 4 barrels of pork; [Witnesses to Indenture, Articles of Agreement][Captain] Nathaniel Sylvester, William Frampton

John Bowne (1627 – 1695) was an English immigrant residing in the Dutch colony of New Netherland, who is honored today as a pioneer in the American struggle for religious liberty. With his wife Hannah Feake (1637 - 1678), great-niece of Governor John Winthrop of Massachusetts, they relocated to Flushing, Long Island in 1661 to practice Quakerism. John Bowne's journal and related papers are preserved at the New York Historical Society.

p.value: Professional Correspondence: 1705 April 16

value.value: Sent From: Isaac Norris of Philadelphia, [PA]
In Reference To: Business / Legal; Veal, Wine Sale

Isaac Norris (July 21, 1671 – June 4, 1735) was a merchant and prominent figure in provincial Pennsylvania, including mayor of Philadelphia in 1724. In 1694 he married Mary, daughter of Thomas Lloyd, president of the council. Their son, Isaac, succeeded his father in business and also became active in politics, serving as speaker of the Assembly. Norris was a slave trader and owner. He and Mary Lloyd freed many of the slaves during their lifetimes or in their wills. Their children, including Elizabeth and Isaac Norris, Jr., freed the rest of them. The Papers of Isaac Norris (1742-1860) are preserved at the Historical Society of Pennsylvania.

value.value: Acquisition: "Articles of Agreement for Dividing and Valuation of Horse Neck & Other Lands in Oyster Bay [Lloyd Neck, Long Island, NY]"
Grantor[s]: John Bowne of [Flushing] & Robert Storey of New York, Attorneys to Thomas Hart of London, [England]

In Reference To: Business / Financial / Professional / Real Estate; C. Lewis Morris with John [Bradenham], London Merchant; Date of Copy Unknown, circa 18th century, dates of original content are September 26, 27, 29 & October 16, 1678; John Ware bill of exchange; S.V. Cortlandt, Mayor; Thomas Cooper with Edward Shipping of Boston, [MA]; Samuel Wilson for 4 barrels of pork; [Witnesses to Indenture, Articles of Agreement][Captain] Nathaniel Sylvester, William Frampton

John Bowne (1627 – 1695) was an English immigrant residing in the Dutch colony of New Netherland, who is honored today as a pioneer in the American struggle for religious liberty. With his wife Hannah Feake (1637 - 1678), great-niece of Governor John Winthrop of Massachusetts, they relocated to Flushing, Long Island in 1661 to practice Quakerism. John Bowne's journal and related papers are preserved at the New York Historical Society.

p.value: Professional Correspondence: 1705 April 16

value.value: Sent From: Isaac Norris of Philadelphia, [PA]
In Reference To: Business / Legal; Veal, Wine Sale

Isaac Norris (July 21, 1671 – June 4, 1735) was a merchant and prominent figure in provincial Pennsylvania, including mayor of Philadelphia in 1724. In 1694 he married Mary, daughter of Thomas Lloyd, president of the council. Their son, Isaac, succeeded his father in business and also became active in politics, serving as speaker of the Assembly. Norris was a slave trader and owner. He and Mary Lloyd freed many of the slaves during their lifetimes or in their wills. Their children, including Elizabeth and Isaac Norris, Jr., freed the rest of them. The Papers of Isaac Norris (1742-1860) are preserved at the Historical Society of Pennsylvania.

p.value: Bates, Charlotte Fiske: [Cambridge, MA]: 1886 December 18

value.value: Charlotte Fiske Bates (Mme. Rogé) (November 30, 1838 – September 1, 1916) was an American writer. Bates published "Risks and Other Poems" (1879) which includes 120 poems, ten sonnets, ten French translations (which were originally done for Longfellow's Poems of Places), and five epithalamia. Bates also contributed many articles to magazines, and edited the Longfellow Birthday Book (1881), Seven Voices of Sympathy(1881), and the Cambridge Book of Poetry and Song(1882). Much of Bates' work is available through New York University Libraries via BobCat.

Hermann Franz Moritz Kopp (October 30, 1817 – February 20, 1892) was a German chemist. Kopp was born at Hanau, where his father, physician Johann Heinrich Kopp (1777 - 1858), was professor of chemistry, physics, and natural history at the local lyceum. Kopp's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

James Russell Lowell (February 22, 1819 – August 12, 1891) was an American Romantic poet, critic, editor, and diplomat. Lowell is associated with the Fireside Poets, a group of New England writers who were among the first American poets who rivaled the popularity of British poets. The James Russell Lowell Papers are preserved at Houghton Library, Harvard University in Cambridge, MA.

August Wilhelm von Hofmann (April 8, 1818 – May 5, 1892) was a German chemist. After studying under Justus von Liebig at the University of Giessen, Hofmann became the first director of the Royal College of Chemistry in London in 1845. In 1865, Hofmann returned to Germany to accept a position at the University of Berlin as a teacher and researcher; he also co-founded the German Chemical Society (Deutsche Chemische Gesellschaft) in 1867. In both London and Berlin, Hofmann recreated the style of laboratory instruction established by Liebig at Giessen, fostering a school of chemistry focused on experimental organic chemistry and its industrial applications. Hofmann archival material is preserved at the Imperial College Archives in London, England.

p.value: Bates, Charlotte Fiske: [Cambridge, MA]: 1886 December 18

value.value: Charlotte Fiske Bates (Mme. Rogé) (November 30, 1838 – September 1, 1916) was an American writer. Bates published "Risks and Other Poems" (1879) which includes 120 poems, ten sonnets, ten French translations (which were originally done for Longfellow's Poems of Places), and five epithalamia. Bates also contributed many articles to magazines, and edited the Longfellow Birthday Book (1881), Seven Voices of Sympathy(1881), and the Cambridge Book of Poetry and Song(1882). Much of Bates' work is available through New York University Libraries via BobCat.

Hermann Franz Moritz Kopp (October 30, 1817 – February 20, 1892) was a German chemist. Kopp was born at Hanau, where his father, physician Johann Heinrich Kopp (1777 - 1858), was professor of chemistry, physics, and natural history at the local lyceum. Kopp's works are available at New York University Libraries via Bobcat.

Alice Mary Longfellow (September 22, 1850 – December 7, 1928) was a philanthropist, preservationist, and the eldest surviving daughter of the American poet Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. Alice is best known as "grave Alice" from her father's poem, "The Children's Hour." Longfellow archival material can be found at the Longfellow National Historic Site in Cambridge, MA.

James Russell Lowell (February 22, 1819 – August 12, 1891) was an American Romantic poet, critic, editor, and diplomat. Lowell is associated with the Fireside Poets, a group of New England writers who were among the first American poets who rivaled the popularity of British poets. The James Russell Lowell Papers are preserved at Houghton Library, Harvard University in Cambridge, MA.

John Gorham Palfrey (May 2, 1796 – April 26, 1881) was an American clergyman and historian who served as a U.S. Representative from Massachusetts. As a Unitarian minister, Palfrey played a leading role in the early history of Harvard Divinity School. The Palfrey Family Papers (1713-1915) are preserved at the Houghton Library, Harvard College Library in Cambridge, MA.

John Wesley Powell (March 24, 1834 – September 23, 1902) was an American educator, explorer of the American West, geologist, and soldier. Powell served as director of the Smithsonian Institution Bureau of Ethnology until his death. The Smithsonian Institute also preserves Powell's artifacts collection in the Department of Anthropology, National Museum of Natural History in Washington, D.C.

Silas Tertius Rand (May 18, 1810 – October 4, 1889) was a Canadian Baptist clergyman and missionary, ethnologist, linguist, and translator. Rand's focus was the Mi'kmaq people of Maritime Canada. Rand archival material can be found at Acadia University Archives in Nova Scotia, Canada, Mount Allison University in New Brunswick, Canada, the Public Archives of Nova Scotia, Canada, and Wellesley College in Wellesley, MA.

dao.title: von Hofmann, August Wilhelm: London, England

p.value: von Hofmann, August Wilhelm: London, England: 1846 April 26

unittitle.value: von Hofmann, August Wilhelm: London, England

value.value: Sent From: "A.W. [August Wilhelm von] Hofmann, Ph.D, Professor of Chemistry, William University at Bonn, [Germany] and Professor at The Royal College of Chemistry, London, Honorary Member of The Royal Agricultural Society of England, 16 Hanover Square, London," [England]
In Reference To: Academic / Business / Education / Professional / Science; Harvard University

August Wilhelm von Hofmann (April 8, 1818 – May 5, 1892) was a German chemist. After studying under Justus von Liebig at the University of Giessen, Hofmann became the first director of the Royal College of Chemistry in London in 1845. In 1865, Hofmann returned to Germany to accept a position at the University of Berlin as a teacher and researcher; he also co-founded the German Chemical Society (Deutsche Chemische Gesellschaft) in 1867. In both London and Berlin, Hofmann recreated the style of laboratory instruction established by Liebig at Giessen, fostering a school of chemistry focused on experimental organic chemistry and its industrial applications. Hofmann archival material is preserved at the Imperial College Archives in London, England.

Sophonisba Preston Breckinridge (April 1, 1866 – July 30, 1948) was an American activist, Progressive Era social reformer, and social scientist. Breckinridge was active in several causes including but not limited to: African American Civil Rights, Children's Protection and Labor Laws Reform, Immigration, Pacifism, Progressive Party, and Women's Suffrage. The Sophonisba Preston Breckinridge Papers (1905-1949) are preserved at the University of Chicago in Chicago, IL, while the Breckinridge Family Papers (1752-1965) are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

Benjamin Apthorp Gould (September 27, 1824 – November 26, 1896) was a pioneering American astronomer. Gould is noted for creating the Astronomical Journal, discovering the Gould Belt, and for founding of the Argentine National Observatory and the Argentine National Weather Service. Gould archival materials can be found at the New York Public Library in New York, NY, and the University of Puget Sound Archives and Special Collections in Tacoma, WA.

Sophonisba Preston Breckinridge (April 1, 1866 – July 30, 1948) was an American activist, Progressive Era social reformer, and social scientist. Breckinridge was active in several causes including but not limited to: African American Civil Rights, Children's Protection and Labor Laws Reform, Immigration, Pacifism, Progressive Party, and Women's Suffrage. The Sophonisba Preston Breckinridge Papers (1905-1949) are preserved at the University of Chicago in Chicago, IL, while the Breckinridge Family Papers (1752-1965) are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

p.value: General U.S. Grant to Edwin M. Stanton: 1865

unittitle.value: Grant, General Ulysses S: City Point, VA

value.value: Addressed To: "Honorable E.M. [Edwin McMasters] Stanton, Secretary of War"
Sent From: "General U.S. [Ulysses S.] Grant, Head Quarters, Army of the Potomac, Office of the Provost Marshall General / City Point, VA," [likely dictated & written by his secretary's hand]
In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science; Professor [Eben Norton] Horsford's ration proposal

Ulysses S. Grant (born Hiram Ulysses Grant; April 27, 1822 – July 23, 1885) was the 18th President of the United States (1869–1877). As Commanding General, Grant worked closely with President Abraham Lincoln to lead the Union Army to victory over the Confederacy in the American Civil War. Grant implemented Congressional Reconstruction, often at odds with Lincoln's successor, Andrew Johnson. Twice elected president, Grant led the Republicans in their effort to remove the vestiges of Confederate nationalism and slavery, protect African-American citizenship, and support economic prosperity nationwide. The Ulysses S. Grant Papers (1844-1922) are preserved at the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

value.value: In Reference To: American Civil War / Business / Food / Military / Politics / Professional / Science

Colonel John Cunningham Kelton (June 24, 1828 – July 15, 1893) was a U.S. Army officer; he served as the Adjutant General of the U.S. Army from 1889 to 1892. Kelton was appointed to the 6th Infantry, in which he served until the outbreak of the American Civil War; he served in various staff positions during the war including the rank Colonel of Volunteers. Kelton correspondence can be found in the Cutts-Madison Papers (1759-1912) at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, MA.
